QU’APPELLE, Protestant Public School District No. 2, of the N.W. Territories.

NOTICE is hereby given that a meeting will be held at Qu’Appelle Hall, in the Town of Qu’Appelle, on Saturday, April 24th, 1886.

SATURDAY, APRIL 24TH, 1886.

For the purpose of taking a vote on the question of raising taxes for the school district, they propose to levy taxes by December 31st, 1886, at the rate of ten cents per $100 assessed valuation, to be assessed in the manner of the last tax levied, and the same to be collected in the same manner as at present, subject to the usual penalties.

The meeting will be called to order at 9 o’clock A.M., and will continue until 12 o’clock noon.

Notice is hereby given that any person who desires to express an opinion on the following question:

“Should taxes be raised to pay the expenses of the school district?”

is respectfully requested to attend the meeting.

Tenders for Bridge.

Tenders addressed to the undersigned, marked “Bridge for Rent,” will be received at the offices of the North-West Council, Regina, until

TUESDAY, THE 30TH DAY OF APRIL, 1886,

whence proceedings shall commence May 1st.

Bridge Across The Qu’Appelle River

on the Town line between Lots 19 and 20, Range 21.

E. DUNWYNE,
Indian Officer, Regina, Indian Commissioner.

Notice to Builders.

TENDERS addressed to the undersigned, marked “Builder’s Bond,” will be received at the offices of the North-West Council, Regina, until

SATURDAY, APRIL 24TH, 1886.

Between the hours of 10 o’clock A.M. and 12 noon.

The specifications of work expressed in the above notice are as follows:

The erection of a building suitable for a school house, containing two rooms, each 16 feet by 20 feet, with a porch 10 feet by 20 feet, and a yard 50 feet square.

The building shall be constructed of brick, with a stone foundation, and shall be completed within six months from the date of contract.

The tenderer must be able to furnish satisfactory references.

T. H. FLEMING,
Superintendent of Bridges.

SUMMERHILL.

Protestant Public School District No. 34, of the N.W. Territories.

NOTICE.

The Trustees of the above named School District, No. 34, of the N.W. Territories, do hereby give notice that a meeting will be held at the school house in the said district, on Saturday, April 24th, 1886, at 10 o’clock A.M., for the purpose of electing a school trustee.

The election will take place at the school house in the said district.

The meeting will be called to order at 10 o’clock A.M., and will continue until 12 o’clock noon.

Notice is hereby given that any person who desires to express an opinion on the following question:

“Should taxes be raised to pay the expenses of the school district?”

is respectfully requested to attend the meeting.

PUBLIC MEETING.

A public meeting of the proprietors of the Thistle Protestant Public School District, No. 35, of the N.W. Territories, is called by order of the Chairman of the Board of Trustees, and will be held at the school house in the said district, on Wednesday, April 25th, 1886, at 10 o’clock A.M., for the purpose of electing a school trustee.

The election will take place at the school house in the said district.

The meeting will be called to order at 10 o’clock A.M., and will continue until 12 o’clock noon.

Notice is hereby given that any person who desires to express an opinion on the following question:

“Should taxes be raised to pay the expenses of the school district?”

is respectfully requested to attend the meeting.

FROM THE CAPITAL.

Ottawa, April 10.—All commissions for officers in the Northwest Mounted Police, except the following, have been announced: Commissary Sergeant Hamilton, Asst. Commis- sioner Crozier; Superintendents Wm. Hemmings, Lottin, McMillan, Gage, Neale, Newell, Macdonald and Jarvis; Commissions for thirty-one inspectors.

The Minister of the Interior in- structed the Dominion Land Surveyors Act, making funds for the act are nearly complete, and others are already in practical operation. An affidavit before the senior clerk in the absence of a local agent, groups of interested parties may obtain titles to land which they may not otherwise obtain.

The minister has also ordered the compilation of maps which will be continued after the 1st of January, 1890, application for patents must be made within three months from the date of issue.

JAMES COWAN,
Qu’Appelle, March 26, 1886.

FORT QU’APPELLE.

We took a trip to Fort Qu’Appelle on Saturday last, and as might be expected when the farmers are seeding, business was quiet. When we descended into the valley and saw the town repose peacefully under the shade of the pine, on either side of the valley, we were forcibly struck with the beauty of the scene. The hills on the south side of the valley are dotted with trees, but the town is built on a level piece of land. The town is built on a piece of land lying between two fine lakes in the valley. Taken altogether the situation is one of beautiful repose, and would be a paradise for any city. We had heard that there was a possibility of sewer drainage, which we understand is not sufficient for the needs of the town, but as it is not sufficiently raised above the level of the lakes, the idea is not, unless the town grows so fast that it will not become a place of any importance. The municipal council we called at the Village Office and found the Postmaster. He was very obliging.

We also met Mr. T. W. Jackson on the street and he invited us up to his house for tea. He is very kind. He informed us that he had just received a letter from Ottawa, saying that the government was going to send a surveyor to examine the land. This will become a very important line and one that should be looked after by the Dominion Government.

The municipal council was in session when we arrived at the office. Mr. M. A. J. Macdonald, all. The council had resolved itself into an audit committee, and were engaged in the books of the municipality. We took a look at the style in which the books were kept, and were very much surprised at their neatness. They are much more elaborate and costly than those kept in any other town in a new country, and if the Council is as extravagant in other matters as they are in the matter of books, we do not wonder that the taxes are high.

— Potatoes wanted at The Pro- vost’s office for subscriptions.
THE COMING STRUGGLE.

British statesmen have commenced the great struggle which will mark the closing years of the present century. This struggle, as appearing in the annals of British history—While writing the Premier Nicholson, who has been advanced in his political career by the election of Lord Liverpool as Premier, the Duke of Wellington, and Lord Lynedoch, have been called together by the Prime Minister, Mr. Gladstone, to consider the financial position of the country. They have discussed the question of the Irish question, and have come to the conclusion that Ireland should be given a greater degree of self-government.

MR. BLAKE'S SPEECH.

From the House of Commons: When Mr. Blake declared, in his speech at Liverpool, that the ballot should be extended to all classes of the community, he said that the ballot was essential, because the majority of voters did not have enough confidence in their representatives. He further stated that the ballot would ensure a fairer division of votes among the candidates. The right hon. member for Liverpool then moved an amendment of his own, which was supported by the hon. members for Manchester and Leeds.

HOME RULE.

Mr. Gladstone has addressed himself to the task of providing Home Rule for Ireland. His proposition is being discussed in both Houses of Parliament. The members of the Irish delegation have visited Westminster to examine the proposals. They have also met with Mr. Gladstone, who has assured them of his support.

A FAMILY MEMORY.

Jabez Weidman, a former colonel of the Maine Volunteers, died at his home in Bangor, Maine, on January 15, 1892. He had been a prominent figure in the Civil War era and had served as a brigadier general during the war. Jabez was born in Maine in 1823 and was educated at Princeton University. He was a member of the New England Bar Association and served as a justice of the peace.

WIT AND HUMOR.

A man was asked why he believed in the doctrine of evolution. He replied, "Because I know God created the earth in six days."
OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of ONE DOLLAR, with the object of endeavoring to make payment. We can much better afford to publish paper at that price when we know that every paper going out is paid for, than if we took the chance of collecting accounts at a higher figure. Besides, we will consequently secure a larger circulation, which will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1887.

Poetry.

SPRINGTIME.

WESTERN POETRY—QU'APPELLE PROGRESS.

Spring is in the air, and spring is doing up
The very best things in the great building.
And spring softly puts in the sweet
smelling chimes,
And spring brings the swallow in from
some glee.

The old homesteaders from each valley and
mountain,
Dreaed in the warmth of the same
sun,
Each humble rose from like a bright
And rippling song is sweet musical lays,
The frogs rend a welcome to beauty.
The bird hops with glees in the sunlight
And birds through the water do dance the
bright,
As the birds capture each bright
golden rays.

The first problem from awakes from her
sleep,
And yawning, does breathe new life over
her.
The flowers are peeping in countless gems,
Which spring into being and bloom at her
side.

FIGHTING DEATH.

The Greenwood Banner tells the following pathetic story of a man fighting death, the last few hours, in order to say goodbye to his wife, who was bedridden, but the effort was vain.

Conductor Fraser, of the Intercolonial & Great Northern Railroad, tried to fight death for five hours, in order that he might see his wife. He had been shot by a trumpeter and was taken to Tyler, Texas, in a dying condition.

"Help me fight back this cruel death," he said to the doctor here," said the dying man, cheerily. The doctors had already told him that there was no hope.

With a calm dignity, he bade the weevil, and called all of his wonder-full force to aid in the struggle to live.

"I tell me exciting stories," he said to the boys around his bed, "for I must die, and you will be left here."

And the boys did laugh, and tell big stories, poor fellows, when the story-teller could not keep up the ra-gits. The hears sped rapidly by; the nervous young man, the conductor grown weak and failing, but his courage never faltered.

A telegram from his wife, in answer to his request, came just before he was brought into the room and raised. She was coming on a special train, the conductor asked for her passage, and with lighting speed her train was annihilating distance. She came in, a young woman in the full flush of health, a new life uplifted against death, the kind of terror. The news moved Fraser in a moment of his life.

Keep up your courage," he said.

"Wait here," whispered a broken man, she will be here in an hour."

"Turn me over, boys," he whispered.

It was done. He whispered to an attendant—"Charley, I cannot run on this schedule—good-bye."

He was dead.

ELEGANT HANDS.

A proper hand can be more un-fashionable than any other face. But just now, we are told, it is particularly "the fashion" to display a proper hand.

That elaborate box of nonsense, the nail-case, made of plush or satin, and lined with attractive little blue silk, may be used in more than usual request.

Girls spend an hour at a time polishing their nails, pink powder a bit of chocolate or, with an instrument made for the purpose, carefully rubbing away the thin film of skin that obscures the white creases at the base of the nail. A fresh coat of varnish is then put on them with dismay, and causes an instant demand for lemon juice.

A hard hand is better suited to searching domestic recipes for the proper composition of almond-paste. A tender hand is less liable to wrist or knuckle plagues the victim in despair.

There is good in all this, but the thing may be carried too far. A young lady's hands should be well cared for, but polished to a high degree, but there are some blunders possible upon its beauty which no one can excuse.

Such is the pictured appearance of the hand of a young lady who has received a wound, the pale, stained fingers of the preserver-keeper, and who would not regard the wound as a mark of a royal pain that has not diminished the dignity of the situation as honorable ones, no more than the disfigurement than the woundcut on the forehead of a soldier.

The tenderer your hands the better they hang below, until they become too heavy to be useful. The plump, round, white hands with a pink palm, tan in a sunburning, the keen, hard hand that is redder and rougher, and does good work, has the first claim upon our admiration.

San Jones, the evangelist, has given the girls a special ser-mon. Among other things he said: "Girls, watch your appearance. Angel Gabriel himself could not keep some company that girls do in Chicago and not be cor-rupted. We must be careful about this on earth for beauty and glory. Boys go in bad company, but the girls must be pure. Mr. Jones urged in a long description and denunciation of the present young women, and described the cause of their downfall as the dud-der-legged dude. Some mothers, he said, fixed their daughters to be little party girls for their children. A little party is a big party in short order. There was a loud party and then the hugging German. I want to have the grass growing on my grave. I want to be among attending Germans. After the Ger-mans, then what? I will not go there. Take care of yourself. If a man found priest who says that at his confessional nineteen out of every twenty young women who has stayed single has their full self-pity and virtue to the influence of the balloon."

The NorWest Farmer

Wants Manitoba

And the North West

To Yield a Greater Return to the Farmer.

We are doing our best to bring about this result by the publication of every intelligent man in prairie provinces.

THE N.O.W. WEST FARMER

AND MANITOBAN MILLER.

In December, 1886, the first and greatest of newspapers in Canada, the Nor-West Farmer, began its career. It has been running ever since, with information, facts and figures, and has been the best medium of practical advice to the farmers and stockmen of the prairies. It is the only independent newspaper ever to be published in the prairies.

HELP ALONG OUR GOOD WORK

By sending in Your Subscription.

Only $1.00 per Year

To everyone who subscribes before Feb. 1st, 1887, we will send a copy of the latest number of the Nor-West Farmer, free of charge.

The Nor-West Farmer Printing Co.

WM. CLARK

J. C. KRAUSLEISDE

QU'APPELLE.

We have made arrangements with the Nor-West Farmer Printing Co., to print our paper, but by purchasing subscriptions we secure the right to use the name of the Nor-West Farmer Printing Co., and to publish our paper under that name.

Editorial.

The paper will be kept to a high standard, and we shall make a firm attempt at the new year to maintain the high standard set by the Nor-West Farmer Printing Co.

Address.

The Business Manager,

Manitoban Office,

Winnipeg, Man.
From the Head-Lines.

-Mr. Moyle & Butte put in tender of their account with the cedar set 30th of March, who thought will be general this week.

-Board of Education has appointed Mr. G. Lary as Inspector of Public Schools in Battleford District and Mr. R. E. Richebe as Inspector of Roman Catholic Schools within its territorial limits.

Mr. J. L. Moyle, sometime Indian Agent here, and lately of Prince Albert, has been appointed Inspector of Public Schools in district of W. H. Hernanl, who has received another appointment. Mr. R. P. Sirwathers, which will plot until he finds his duties will make him altogether out of the country.

-Already evidences are everywhere that lumbering operations will begin this coming day on a scale unprecedented in the history of the town. Logs for a large part of buildings which have begun to be erected or are being moved by many people are anxiously awaited Long the banks of the river to be down material for building. The saw-mill have been made ready to run a heavy customer's work, and in addition to this they own material, their yards are supplied with customer's logs.

CONSUMPTION CURED

An old physician, retired from practice, having placed in his hands by an East Indian missionary the formula of a simple vegetable mixture (wholly free from all animal and-one of consumption, Brennand's Cordials, Austin Avenue and Main Street. Toronto, Canada) and all thirst and vague intestinal symptoms, besides Nervous Debility and Nervous Complaints, after having for several years suffered powers often threatened, has left it difficult to make known to his enduring followers, but also for more than 75 cases, how they can be relieved from suffering. I will send free of charge those desiring to become acquainted with its advantages, whether it be French or English, just fill in the blank below and mail the request, answers will be mailed.

W. J. NELSON. 156 Victoria Street, Toronto, Ont.

ANGLO-CANADIAN CHURCH.

Sundays—Morning service at 12 o'clock (Post) and every Sunday. Holy Communion once a month on the first Sunday of each (Sunday) year (except Sunday).

Services at 11 half past each Sunday.

Rev. F. W. Hill.

PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH.

Services of 9 o'clock every Sabbath morning at 11 o'clock and evening at 7 o'clock.

Rev. W. C. Smith, minister.

PRE-EMINENT METHODIST.

Services of 9 o'clock every Sabbath morning at 11 o'clock and evening at 7 o'clock.

Rev. J. Wilson.

ROYAL TIMOTHIES.

Hughes meeting in the Methodist Church every Monday evening 8 o'clock. Rev. T. Lawrence, S. C. Dr. F. Froize.

ROSSIANS.

Regular meetings by subscription held every Saturday afternoon at half past 4 o'clock.

ROYAL TIMOTHIES.

Hughes meeting in the Methodist Church at noon Friday, Saturday and Sunday morning at 11 o'clock. Popular meetings held in the Baptist Church.

NOTICE OF DISSOLUTION OF CO-OPERATIONSHIP.

The Company of Proprietors engaged in producing the finest and most sustaining form of Vegetable Food called the "Dise and Biscuit," under the name of Western Bakery, is dissolved voluntarily by mutual consent of all partners. Each party, and Partners of other firms are authorized to enter into contracts with each other and with any person who may desire to do so in order to continue the business without farther delay.
HOME & GOSSIP.
Qu'Appelle

Building lovely.
Encouragement.
Join the building society.
Farmers correspondingly happy.
Work has been commenced on the cellar of Mr. C. Gibson's new bakery.

Mr. A. McKeowne's new bakery is rapidly approaching completion.

A large fruit load of corn and other produce for the Indian Department at Weyburn was delivered.

Nine of our business places have put in telephones. A conversation from the east is talked of with ease.

No crossing will take place between 23rd and 24th of March unless by special permission through the authorities.

— The Inland Revenue Act. Mr. J. Z. McGowan has been appointed supervisor at the Assiniboia In-gathering Office. He has also been appointed Assistant Director at Calgary. Mr. McGowan has the entire control of the six men who make up his office. The three years he has been in our midst doubtless supersedes Mr. J. Z. McGowan. Mr. Matacoad is very active in his duties, and we hope he will continue to be so.

The prospects for the wheat crop in the central districts appear promising. The rains have been most liberal, and the crops look well. Mr. E. Butler expresses a great deal of satisfaction with the condition of the crops. Mr. Butler has always been a keen observer of weather conditions.

Roller Mills, Qu'Appelle

We are pleased to announce that our Roller Mills at Qu'Appelle Station, are now in operation; and that we are prepared to supply the Farmers of the Municipality of Qu'Appelle, with Flour, and oil seeds, and Shales, in exchange for Wheat.

Qu'Appelle Agricultural Society

Saturday, May 1st, 1886.

Notice

The above is a true copy of the proceedings held at a meeting of the Council of the Township of Qu'Appelle, held on May 7th, 1886, and recorded by the Secretary.
